Acca of Hexham.label: Acca of Hexham
Acca of Hexham.description: Saint Acca of Hexham was a Northumbrian saint and Bishop of Hexham from 709 until 732. Wikipedia

Atto of Pistoia.label: Atto of Pistoia
Atto of Pistoia.description:
Atto of Pistoia was a Portuguese-born 12th-century prelate and historiographer in Italy.
He was born at Beja in the Portuguese region of Alentejo in 1070. Wikipedia

Émilie Gamelin.label: Émilie Gamelin
Émilie Gamelin.description: Émilie Tavernier Gamelin, S.P., was a French Canadian social worker and Roman Catholic Religious Sister. She is best known as the founder of the Sisters of Providence of Montreal. In 2001 she was beatified by Pope John Paul II. Wikipedia

Ansovinus.label: Ansovinus
Ansovinus.description: Saint Ansovinus was a bishop of Camerino. Born in Camerino, he may have been of Lombard origin, and was educated at the cathedral school of Pavia. He was a hermit at Castel Raimondo near Torcello. Wikipedia

Brice of Tours.label: Brice of Tours
Brice of Tours.description:
Saint Brice of Tours was the fourth Bishop of Tours, succeeding Martin of Tours in 397.
According to legend, Brice was an orphan rescued by Martin and raised in the monastery at Marmoutiers. Wikipedia

Austregisilus.label: Austregisilus
Austregisilus.description: Saint Austregisilus was bishop of Bourges from 612 to 624. His feast day is May 20. A native of Bourges, he was educated as a courtier. Wikipedia

Daniel Comboni.label: Daniel Comboni
Daniel Comboni.description: Daniel Comboni was a Roman Catholic missionary to Africa and saint. Wikipedia

Bernward of Hildesheim.label: Bernward of Hildesheim
Bernward of Hildesheim.description: Saint Bernward was the thirteenth Bishop of Hildesheim from 993 until his death in 1022. Wikipedia

Alban of Mainz.label: Alban of Mainz
Alban of Mainz.description:
Saint Alban of Mainz was a priest, missionary, and martyr.
Rabanus Maurus wrote in his Martyrology about Alban, who was sent to Gallia as a missionary by Ambrose of Milan. In Mainz, Alban helped bishop Aureus of Mainz to regain his bishopric. Wikipedia

Adolph Kolping.label: Adolph Kolping
Adolph Kolping.description: Adolph Kolping was a German Catholic priest, who has been beatified by the Catholic Church. He was a leader in providing social support for young workers in the cities of industrial Germany, and worldwide. Wikipedia

César de Bus.label: César de Bus
César de Bus.description: Blessed César de Bus was a French Catholic priest, founder of two religious congregations. Wikipedia

Ansegisus.label: Ansegisus
Ansegisus.description:
Saint Ansegisus was a monastic reformer of the Franks.
Born about 770, of noble parentage, at the age of eighteen he entered the Benedictine monastery of Fontanelle in the diocese of Rouen. Wikipedia

Antoninus of Sorrento.label: Antoninus of Sorrento
Antoninus of Sorrento.description:
Antoninus of Sorrento was an Italian abbot, hermit, and saint.
Born at Campagna, he left his native town to become a monk at Monte Cassino. Wikipedia

Albert of Louvain.label: Albert of Louvain
Albert of Louvain.description: Saint Albert of Louvain or Albert of Leuven was Prince-Bishop of Liège from 22 September 1191 till January 1192. He was canonized in 1613. Wikipedia

Conrad of Constance.label: Conrad of Constance
Conrad of Constance.description: Saint Conrad of Constance was a bishop and saint. Wikipedia

Demetrius of Thessaloniki.label: Demetrius of Thessaloniki
Demetrius of Thessaloniki.description:
Saint Demetrius of Thessaloniki is a Christian martyr of the early 4th century.
During the Middle Ages, he came to be revered as one of the most important Orthodox military saints, often paired with Saint George. Wikipedia

Bruno (Bishop of Würzburg).label: Bruno
Bruno (Bishop of Würzburg).description: Bruno of Würzburg, also known as Bruno of Carinthia, was imperial chancellor of Italy from 1027 to 1034 for Conrad II, Holy Roman Emperor, to whom he was related, and from 1034 until his death prince-bishop of Würzburg. Wikipedia

Arnold Janssen.label: Arnold Janssen
Arnold Janssen.description: Saint Arnold Janssen, S.V.D. was a Roman Catholic priest and missionary, and is venerated as a saint. Wikipedia

Dominguito del Val.label: Dominguito del Val
Dominguito del Val.description: Saint Dominguito del Val was, allegedly, a choirboy ritually murdered by Jews in Zaragoza. Dominguito's story is related to the blood libel against Jews that grew in prominence in the 12th and 13th ... Wikipedia

Angilbert.label: Angilbert
Angilbert.description: Saint Angilbert was a Frank who served Charlemagne as a diplomat, abbot, poet and semi-son-in-law. He was of noble Frankish parentage, and educated at the palace school in Aquae Grani under Alcuin. Wikipedia

Agathoclia.label: Agathoclia
Agathoclia.description: Saint Agathoclia is venerated as a patron saint of Mequinenza, Aragón, Spain. Her feast day is September 17. Wikipedia

Adelaide, Abbess of Vilich.label: Adelaide, Abbess of Vilich
Adelaide, Abbess of Vilich.description: Adelaide, Abbess of Vilich, also known as Adelheid, was a daughter of Megingoz des Brunharingen, Count of Guelders, and Gerberga of Metzgau, a granddaughter of Charles the Simple, king of the West Franks. Wikipedia

Anna Maria Taigi.label: Anna Maria Taigi
Anna Maria Taigi.description: Anna Maria Gesualda Antonia Taigi was an Italian housewife, ecstatic and seer who was beatified by Pope Benedict XV in 1920. Wikipedia

Anselm, Duke of Friuli.label: Anselm, Duke of Friuli
Anselm, Duke of Friuli.description: Anselm, the Duke of Forum Julii in the northeastern part of Lombard Italy, left the world at the height of his secular career, and in 750 built a monastery at Fanano, a place given to him by Aistulf, ... Wikipedia

Brendan of Birr.label: Brendan of Birr
Brendan of Birr.description: Saint Brendan of Birr was one of the early Irish monastic saints. He was a monk and later an abbot, of the 6th century. He is known as "St Brendan the Elder" to distinguish him from his contemporary and friend St Brendan the Navigator of Clonfert. Wikipedia

Daniel the Stylite.label: Daniel the Stylite
Daniel the Stylite.description: Saint Daniel the Stylite is a saint of the Eastern Orthodox, and Roman Catholic and Eastern Catholic Churches. He was born in a village by the name of Maratha in upper Mesopotamia near Samosata, in today what is now a region of Turkey. Wikipedia

Andrey Bogolyubsky.label: Andrey Bogolyubsky
Andrey Bogolyubsky.description: Prince Andrei I of Vladimir, commonly known as Andrey Bogolyubsky was a prince of Vladimir-Suzdal. He was the son of Yuri Dolgoruki, who proclaimed Andrei a prince in Vyshhorod. Wikipedia

Æthelthryth.label: Æthelthryth
Æthelthryth.description: Æthelthryth is the name for the Anglo-Saxon saint known, particularly in a religious context, as Etheldreda or Audrey. She was an East Anglian princess, a Fenland and Northumbrian queen and Abbess of Ely. Wikipedia

Anne Catherine Emmerich.label: Anne Catherine Emmerich
Anne Catherine Emmerich.description: Blessed Anne Catherine Emmerich was a Roman Catholic Augustinian Canoness Regular of Windesheim, stigmatic, mystic, visionary and ecstatic. Wikipedia

Corbinian.label: Corbinian
Corbinian.description: Saint Corbinian was a Frankish bishop. After living as a hermit near Chartres for fourteen years, he made a pilgrimage to Rome. Pope Gregory II sent him to Bavaria. Wikipedia

Dominic Barberi.label: Dominic Barberi
Dominic Barberi.description: Blessed Dominic of the Mother of God, born Dominic Barberi was an Italian theologian and a member of the Passionist Congregation. He was beatified by Pope Paul VI in 1963. Wikipedia

Antoninus of Florence.label: Antoninus of Florence
Antoninus of Florence.description: Saint Antoninus of Florence, O.P., was an Italian Dominican friar, who ruled as an Archbishop of Florence. He is venerated as a saint by the Catholic Church. Wikipedia

Ceolfrith.label: Ceolfrith
Ceolfrith.description: Saint Ceolfrid was an Anglo-Saxon Christian abbot and saint. He is best known as the warden of Bede from the age of seven until his death in 716. He was the Abbot of Monkwearmouth-Jarrow Abbey, and a major contributor to the project Codex Amiatinus. Wikipedia

Adela and Irmina.label: Adela and Irmina
Adela and Irmina.description: Saint Adela and Saint Irmina were two princesses, the daughters of Saint Dagobert II. Wikipedia

Alberto Marvelli.label: Alberto Marvelli
Alberto Marvelli.description:
Alberto Marvelli was an Italian member of the Catholic Action.
Born at Ferrara, he was given a Christian formation by his mother, who kept their home open to the poor. Through his upbringing he became a firm defender of the poor in his later years. Wikipedia

Chromatius.label: Chromatius
Chromatius.description:
Saint Chromatius was a bishop of Aquileia.
He was probably born at Aquileia, and in any case grew up there. His father had died when Chromatius was an infant. He was raised by his mother and large family of older siblings. Wikipedia

Columba of Spain.label: Columba of Spain
Columba of Spain.description:
Saint Columba of Spain, or Columba of Cordova, was a nun who was born in Cordoba, Spain and died around 853.
She was a nun at Tabanos, near Cordoba, but was driven from there by the Moorish persecution in 852. Wikipedia

Catherine of Bologna.label: Catherine of Bologna
Catherine of Bologna.description:
Saint Catherine of Bologna, O.S.C. was an Italian cloistered nun, artist and saint.
The patron saint of artists and against temptations, Catherine de'Vigri was venerated for nearly three centuries in ... Wikipedia

Burchard of Würzburg.label: Burchard of Würzburg
Burchard of Würzburg.description:
Burchard of Würzburg was a Bishop of Würzburg in 741–754.
He was an Anglo-Saxon who left England after the death of his kinsfolk and joined Boniface in his missionary labors, some time after 732. Wikipedia

Carlos Manuel Rodríguez Santiago.label: Carlos Manuel Rodríguez Santiago
Carlos Manuel Rodríguez Santiago.description: Blessed Carlos Manuel Rodríguez Santiago was born in Caguas, Puerto Rico. Rodríguez was a layperson of the Roman Catholic Church, who was beatified on April 29, 2001. Wikipedia

Bartolo Longo.label: Bartolo Longo
Bartolo Longo.description: Blessed Bartolo Longo was a Satanist priest who later repented and became a lay Dominican, dedicating his life to the Virgin Mary. He was eventually awarded a papal knighthood. Wikipedia

Candida Maria of Jesus.label: Candida Maria of Jesus
Candida Maria of Jesus.description: Saint Candida Maria of Jesus, F.I., was a Spanish Religious Sister and educator. She founded the Spanish Congregation of the Daughters of Jesus on 8 December 1871 in Salamanca, Spain. Wikipedia

Ceferino Namuncurá.label: Ceferino Namuncurá
Ceferino Namuncurá.description: Blessed Ceferino Namuncurá was a saintly religious student and the object of a Roman Catholic cultus of veneration in northern Patagonia and throughout Argentina. Wikipedia

Christina the Astonishing.label: Christina the Astonishing
Christina the Astonishing.description: Christina the Astonishing, also known as Christina Mirabilis, was a Christian holy-woman born in Brustem. She was considered a saint in contemporary times. Wikipedia

Edel Quinn.label: Edel Quinn
Edel Quinn.description:
The Venerable Edel Mary Quinn was an Irish lay missionary.
Born in Kanturk, County Cork, Edel was the eldest child of bank official Charles Quinn and Louisa Burke Browne of County Clare. Wikipedia

Eulogius of Alexandria.label: Eulogius of Alexandria
Eulogius of Alexandria.description: Saint Eulogius of Alexandria was Greek Patriarch of that see from 580 to 608. He is regarded as a saint, with a feast day of September 13. Wikipedia

Eanflæd.label: Eanflæd
Eanflæd.description: Eanflæd was a Kentish princess, queen of Northumbria and later, the abbess of an influential Christian monastery in Whitby, England. Wikipedia

Elizabeth of Schönau.label: Elizabeth of Schönau
Elizabeth of Schönau.description: Elizabeth of Schönau was a German Benedictine visionary. When her writings were published, the title of "Saint" was added to her name. She was never canonized, but in 1584 her name was entered in the Roman Martyrology and has remained there. Wikipedia

Epiphanius of Pavia.label: Epiphanius of Pavia
Epiphanius of Pavia.description: Epiphanius of Pavia, later venerated as Saint Epiphanius of Pavia, was Bishop of Pavia from 466 until his death in 496. Epiphanius additionally held the offices of lector, subdeacon and deacon. Wikipedia

Edmund Ignatius Rice.label: Edmund Ignatius Rice
Edmund Ignatius Rice.description: Blessed Edmund Ignatius Rice, was a Roman Catholic missionary and educationalist. Edmund was the founder of two religious institutes of religious brothers the Congregation of Christian Brothers and the Presentation Brothers. Wikipedia

Eustochium.label: Eustochium
Eustochium.description: Saint Eustochium. Born Eustochium Julia at Rome, she was the daughter of Saint Paula and is also venerated as a saint and was an early Desert Mother. Wikipedia

Eucharius.label: Eucharius
Eucharius.description: Saint Eucharius is venerated as the first bishop of Trier. He lived in the second half of the 3rd century. Wikipedia

Galgano Guidotti.label: Galgano Guidotti
Galgano Guidotti.description:
Saint Galgano is a Catholic saint from Tuscany.
He was born in Chiusdino, in the modern province of Siena, Italy, from Guidotto and Dionigia. Wikipedia

Ezequiel Moreno y Díaz.label: Ezequiel Moreno y Díaz
Ezequiel Moreno y Díaz.description: Ezequiél Moreno y Díaz was a member of the Order of Augustinian Recollects and now venerated as a Saint in the Roman Catholic Church. He was born on April 9, 1848 in Alfaro, La Rioja, Spain and later on served as a missionary to the Philippines. Wikipedia

Francesco Faà di Bruno.label: Francesco Faà di Bruno
Francesco Faà di Bruno.description: The Blessed Francesco Faà di Bruno was an Italian priest and advocate of the poor, as well being a leading mathematician of his era and a noted religious musician. In 1988 he was beatified by Pope John Paul II. Wikipedia

Fridianus.label: Fridianus
Fridianus.description: Saint Fridianus, was an Irish prince and hermit, fl. 6th century. Tradition names him as a son of King Ultach of Ulster. He later became Bishop of Lucca in Italy. The Basilica of San Frediano in the city is dedicated to him. Wikipedia

Gatianus of Tours.label: Gatianus of Tours
Gatianus of Tours.description: Gatianus was the founding bishop of the see of Tours. Wikipedia

Fulgentius of Ruspe.label: Fulgentius of Ruspe
Fulgentius of Ruspe.description: Saint Fulgentius of Ruspe was bishop of the city of Ruspe, North Africa, in the 5th and 6th century and was canonized as a Christian saint. Wikipedia

Goar of Aquitaine.label: Goar of Aquitaine
Goar of Aquitaine.description: Saint Goar of Aquitaine was a priest and hermit of the seventh century. He was offered the position of Bishop of Trier, but died before accepting the position. He is noted for his piety, and is revered as a miracle-worker. Wikipedia

Gerald of Braga.label: Gerald of Braga
Gerald of Braga.description: Gerald of Braga, born in Cahors, Gascony, was a Benedictine monk at Moissac, France. He later worked with the archbishop in Toledo, Spain, and served as cathedral choir director. Wikipedia

Fridolin of Säckingen.label: Fridolin of Säckingen
Fridolin of Säckingen.description: Saint Fridolin, otherwise Fridolin of Säckingen, traditionally believed to have been born in Ireland, was a missionary, and the founder of Säckingen Abbey, Baden, in the 6th or 7th century. He is honoured as the apostle of the Alamanns. Wikipedia

Gaspar del Bufalo.label: Gaspar del Bufalo
Gaspar del Bufalo.description: Saint Gaspar del Bufalo, also known as Gaspare del Bufalo, was a Roman Catholic priest and the founder of the Missionaries of the Precious Blood. Wikipedia

Gangulphus.label: Gangulphus
Gangulphus.description: Saint Gangulphus of Burgundy is venerated as a martyr by the Catholic Church. Gangulphus was a Burgundian courtier whose historical existence can only be attested by a single document a deed from the court of Pepin the Short dated 762. Wikipedia

Gianna Beretta Molla.label: Gianna Beretta Molla
Gianna Beretta Molla.description: Saint Gianna Beretta Molla was an Italian pediatrician, wife and mother who is best known for refusing both an abortion and a hysterectomy when she was pregnant with her fourth child, despite knowing ... Wikipedia

Geminianus.label: Geminianus
Geminianus.description: Saint Geminianus was a fourth century Deacon, and later Bishop of Modena. He is mentioned in the year 390 when he sent a delegate named Teodulo to participate in a council called by Saint Ambrose in Milan. Wikipedia

Frumentius.label: Frumentius
Frumentius.description:
Saint Frumentius was the first Bishop of Aksum, and he is credited with bringing Christianity to the Aksumite Kingdom.
He was a Syro-Phoenician Greek born in Tyre. Captured with his brother as a boy, they became slaves to the King of Axum. Wikipedia

Herculanus of Perugia.label: Herculanus of Perugia
Herculanus of Perugia.description: Saint Herculanus of Perugia was a bishop of Perugia and is patron saint of that city. His main feast day is November 7; his second feast is celebrated on March 1. Wikipedia

Hud (prophet).label: Hud
Hud (prophet).description: Hud is the name of a prophet of ancient Arabia, who is mentioned in the Qur'an. The eleventh chapter of the Qur'an, Hud, is named after him, though the narrative of Hud comprises only a small portion of the chapter. Wikipedia

Gottschalk (Obotrite prince).label: Gottschalk
Gottschalk (Obotrite prince).description: Saint Gottschalk was a prince of the Obotrite confederacy from 1043 to 1066. He established a Slavic kingdom on the Elbe in the mid-11th century. Wikipedia

Idris (prophet).label: Idris
Idris (prophet).description: Idris‘ is an ancient prophet mentioned in the Qur'an. He is described in the Qur'an as "trustworthy" and "patient" and the Qur'an also says that he was "exalted to a high station", which has generally ... Wikipedia

Gondulph of Maastricht.label: Gondulph of Maastricht
Gondulph of Maastricht.description: Gondulph of Maastricht, sometimes of Tongeren was a Bishop of Tongeren-Maastricht and is venerated as a Roman Catholic saint. Saint Gondulph is a patron saint of the city of Maastricht together with Saint Monulph. Wikipedia

Hospitius.label: Hospitius
Hospitius.description: Saint Hospitius was a French recluse who, according to tradition, had been a monk in his native Egypt towards the beginning of the 6th century. Wikipedia

Ignatius of Laconi.label: Ignatius of Laconi
Ignatius of Laconi.description: Saint Ignatius was a Sardinian Capuchin monk and saint. During a serious illness as a young man he made a vowed that, if he recovered his health, he would consecrate his life to God in the Order of Friars Minor Capuchin. Wikipedia

Gorgonius.label: Gorgonius
Gorgonius.description: Saint Gorgonius of Nicomedia was a Christian martyr, part of the group Gorgonius, Peter Cubicularius and Dorotheus, who died in 304 AD at Nicomedia during the persecution of Emperor Diocletian. Wikipedia

John and Paul.label: John and Paul
John and Paul.description: John and Paul are saints in the Roman Catholic Church. They were martyred at Rome on 26 June. They should not be confused with the famous apostles of the same name. Wikipedia

Ignatius Bryanchaninov.label: Ignatius Bryanchaninov
Ignatius Bryanchaninov.description:
Saint Ignatius is a bishop and theologian of the Russian Orthodox Church.
He was born to a wealthy landowning family. He was educated at Main Military Engineering School in St. Petersburg. Wikipedia

Innocenzo da Berzo.label: Innocenzo da Berzo
Innocenzo da Berzo.description: Blessed Innocenzo da Berzo was born in Niardo, Val Camonica, Italy on 19 March 1844. His parents were Pietro Scalvinoni and Francesca Poli. He was baptized with the name of Giovanni. Wikipedia

John of Dukla.label: John of Dukla
John of Dukla.description: John of Dukla is a saint in the Roman Catholic Church. He is one of the patron saints of Poland and Lithuania. Wikipedia

John the Iberian.label: John the Iberian
John the Iberian.description: John the Iberian was a Georgian monk, who is venerated as a saint. A member of the Georgian nobility, he was married and served as a military commander. Wikipedia

John of Gorze.label: John of Gorze
John of Gorze.description: Saint John of Gorze was a Lorraine-born monk, diplomat, administrator, and monastic reformer. Wikipedia

John the Russian.label: John the Russian
John the Russian.description: Saint John the Russian is one of the most renowned saints in the Greek Orthodox Church. Being a prisoner of war and a slave to a Turkish Agha, he became famous and respected even by his Muslim master ... Wikipedia

Justus of Beauvais.label: Justus of Beauvais
Justus of Beauvais.description: Saint Justus of Beauvais is a semi-legendary saint of the Roman Catholic Church. He may have been a Gallo-Roman martyr, but his legend was confused with that of other saints, such as Justin of Paris. Wikipedia

Jordan of Saxony.label: Jordan of Saxony
Jordan of Saxony.description: The Blessed Jordan of Saxony, O.P., was one of the first leaders of the Dominican Order. His feast day is February 15. Wikipedia

Judas Cyriacus.label: Judas Cyriacus
Judas Cyriacus.description: Judas Cyriacus is the patron saint of Ancona, Italy. His feast day is celebrated in the Catholic Church on May 4. Wikipedia

Luchesio Modestini.label: Luchesius Modestini
Luchesio Modestini.description: Luchesius Modestini was a native and merchant of the town of Poggibonsi in the Province of Siena around 1180-1182. Wikipedia

Marie Louise Trichet.label: Marie Louise Trichet
Marie Louise Trichet.description: Blessed Marie Louise Trichet, also known as Marie-Louise de Jésus, was a French Catholic figure who, with Saint Louis de Montfort, founded the Congregation of religious women called Daughters of Wisdom ... Wikipedia

Miguel Pro.label: Miguel Pro
Miguel Pro.description: José Ramón Miguel Agustín Pro Juárez also known as Blessed Miguel Pro, was a Mexican Jesuit Catholic priest executed under the presidency of Plutarco Elías Calles on trumped up charges of bombing ... Wikipedia

Justin Popović.label: Justin Popović
Justin Popović.description: Saint Iustin Popović was an Eastern Orthodox theologian, archimandrite of the Ćelije Monastery, Dostoyevsky scholar, a champion of anti-communism, a writer, and a critic of the pragmatic church life. On the April 29, 2010, Fr. Wikipedia

Kuriakose Elias Chavara.label: Kuriakose Elias Chavara
Kuriakose Elias Chavara.description: Kuriakose Elias Chavara, T.O.C.D., was the co-founder and first Prior General of the first congregation for men in the Syro-Malabar Catholic Church, now known as the Carmelites of Mary Immaculate, and ... Wikipedia

Justus of Trieste.label: Justus of Trieste
Justus of Trieste.description:
Saint Justus of Trieste is a Roman Catholic saint.
According to his passio, he was a citizen of Triest in Italy, known for his works and charities. Wikipedia

Lutgardis.label: Lutgardis
Lutgardis.description: Saint Lutgardis of Aywières was a Flemish saint. She was born in Tongres in Belgium, and entered into religious orders at the age of twelve. Wikipedia

Juan Diego.label: Juan Diego
Juan Diego.description: St. Juan Diego Cuauhtlatoatzin is the first Roman Catholic indigenous American saint. He is said to have been granted an apparition of the Virgin Mary on four separate occasions in December 1531 at the ... Wikipedia

Marina the Monk.label: Marina the Monk
Marina the Monk.description: Saint Marina the Monk was a 5th-century christian saint of Roman occupied northern Syria. Wikipedia

Malo (saint).label: Saint-Malo
Malo (saint).description:
Saint-Malo is a walled port city in Brittany in northwestern France on the English Channel. It is a sub-prefecture of the Ille-et-Vilaine.
Traditionally with an independent streak, Saint-Malo was in the past notorious for piracy. Wikipedia

Leonard of Noblac.label: Leonard of Noblac
Leonard of Noblac.description: Leonard of Noblac or of Limoges or de Noblet, is a Frankish saint closely associated with the town and abbey of Saint-Léonard-de-Noblat, in Haute-Vienne, in the Limousin of France. Wikipedia

Joseph Vaz.label: Joseph Vaz
Joseph Vaz.description:
Blessed Joseph Vaz, CO, was a Catholic Oratorian priest from Goa. He is known as the 'Apostle of Ceylon'. On 21 January 1995, he was beatified by Pope John Paul II in Colombo.
Fr. Wikipedia

Maris, Martha, Abachum and Audifax.label: Marius, Martha, Audifax, and Abachum
Maris, Martha, Abachum and Audifax.description: Saints Marius, Martha, Audifax, and Abachum were, according to their largely legendary passio of the 6th century, four saints of the same family. Wikipedia

Mary Euphrasia Pelletier.label: Mary Euphrasia Pelletier
Mary Euphrasia Pelletier.description: Saint Mary Euphrasia Pelletier, born Rose Virginie Pelletier, was a French Roman Catholic nun, best known as the foundress of the Congregation of Our Lady of Charity of the Good Shepherd. Wikipedia
